content.webTitle: Celtic keep up treble pursuit with Tom Rogic seeing off Hearts

fields.headline: Celtic keep up treble pursuit with Tom Rogic seeing off Hearts
fields.bodyText: A significant run of games for Celtic has started in positive fashion for Ronny Deila. With matches against Aberdeen and Molde looming, Celtic progressed to the last four of the League Cup with success over a Hearts team who should rue their overcaution. The fact this was a forgettable match will matter little to Deila, who still has a domestic treble in his sights. Celtic’s preparations suffered late disruption, their captain, Scott Brown, incurring an injury in the warm-up and having to be replaced by James Forrest. One of the visiting substitutes, Gary Mackay-Steven, was also hurt at the same point, forcing him to sit out proceedings entirely. Emilio Izaguirre, who required stitches after a training ground altercation with Nadir Ciftci on Tuesday, returned as Celtic’s left-back. The opening period was tepid, a notable aspect in itself for a fixture which commonly lacks nothing in bite. Hearts’ approach was clear; to allow Celtic to dominate possession before using the pace available on both flanks to attack where possible. The aim was to frustrate Deila and his players. Celtic duly enjoyed plenty of the ball but created little. A series of corners offered their finest opportunities, while Hearts’ Osman Sow went close to breaking the deadlock at the opposite end. Celtic’s finest spell of football came in the dying moments of the half but no one was on hand to convert an excellent low cross from Forrest. Hearts had the ball in the net shortly after the hour mark, only for Sow to be flagged offside. It was a warning the cup holders appeared to heed. Celtic’s play had been enhanced by the arrival of Tom Rogic, who replaced Forrest. It was another midfielder, Stefan Johansen, who created the chance that sent Deila’s team ahead. Johansen beat Morgaro Gomis to the ball before feeding Leigh Griffiths, who still had work to do; the striker bamboozled the Hearts back line before offering a fine, curling finish. Griffiths was involved as the lead was doubled. He hit the byline before providing a low cross, which Rogic flicked home. Hearts’ response arrived too late, Arnaud Djoum finding the net with a header.
